SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/org.apache.systemml:systemml: 1

  • org.apache.sysml.test.integration.functions.indexing.RightIndexingMatrixTest.testRightIndexingDenseCP
Thanks @nakul02 I will merge :+1:

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1990/

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1991/

Example DML:
```
x = matrix("1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8", rows=2, cols=4)
y = matrix("1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9", rows=3, cols=3);
z = x + y
...
a = read("data/A.zzz");
...
a = TRUE;
b = FALSE;
c = (a && b)
...
x = matrix("1 2 3 4 5 6", rows=2, cols=3)
[P, L, U] = lu(x)
...
a = blah("hi");
...
x = matrix("1 2 3 4", rows=2, cols=2)
y = table(x)
...
a = min(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
...
a = min(1)
...
a=matrix("1 2 3 4", rows=2, cols=2);
print(a);
```

Previous output:
```
Invalid Parameters : ERROR: ex.dml -- line 4, column 4 -- Mismatch in dimensions for operation (x PLUS y)
Invalid Parameters : ERROR: ex.dml -- line 10, column 2 -- Read input file does not exist on FS (local mode): data/A.zzz
Unsupported Parameters : ERROR: ex.dml -- line 12, column 4 -- Unsupported boolean operation CONDITIONALAND
ERROR: ex.dml -- line 16, column 0 -- LU Decomposition can only be done on a square matrix. Input matrix is rectangular (rows=2, cols=3)
ERROR: ex.dml -- line 19, column 0 -- function blah is undefined in namespace .defaultNS
Invalid Parameters : ERROR: ex.dml -- line 23, column 0 -- Invalid number of arguments to table(): TABLE(x)
Invalid Parameters : ERROR: ex.dml -- line 26, column 0 -- Invalid number of parameters for function MIN
Unsupported Parameters : ERROR: ex.dml -- line 29, column 0 -- Expecting matrix parameter for function MIN
ERROR: ex.dml -- line 33, column 0 -- print statement can only print scalars
```

New output:
```
ERROR: ex.dml [line 4:4] -> x + y -- Mismatch in dimensions for operation 'x + y'. x is 2x4 and y is 3x3.
ERROR: ex.dml [line 10:2] -> a = read("data/A.zzz"); -- Read input file does not exist on FS (local mode): data/A.zzz
ERROR: ex.dml [line 12:4] -> (a && b) -- Conditional AND (&&) not supported.
ERROR: ex.dml [line 16:0] -> [P, L, U] = lu(x) -- LU Decomposition requires a square matrix. Matrix x is 2x3.
ERROR: ex.dml [line 19:0] -> a = blah("hi"); -- Function blah() is undefined.
ERROR: ex.dml [line 23:0] -> y = table(x) -- Invalid number of arguments to table(). The table() function requires 2, 3, 4, or 5 arguments.
ERROR: ex.dml [line 26:0] -> a = min(1, 2, 3, 4, 5) -- Invalid number of arguments for function min(). This function only takes 1 or 2 arguments.
ERROR: ex.dml [line 29:0] -> a = min(1) -- Expecting matrix argument for function min().
ERROR: ex.dml [line 33:0] -> print(a); -- Print statements can only print scalars. To print a matrix, please wrap it in a toString() function.
```
Thanks for reviewing @gweidner
thanks for addressing the review comments @j143. This LGTM.

PyDML text processing now generates similar results to DML.
```
x = full("1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8", rows=2, cols=4)
y = full("1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9", rows=3, cols=3)
z = x + y
#ERROR: ex.dml [line 4:4] -> x + y -- Mismatch in dimensions for operation 'x + y'. x is 2x4 and y is 3x3.
#ERROR: ex.pydml [line 4:4] -> x + y -- Mismatch in dimensions for operation 'x + y'. x is 2x4 and y is 3x3.

a = load("data/A.zzz")
#ERROR: ex.dml [line 10:2] -> a = read("data/A.zzz"); -- Read input file does not exist on FS (local mode): data/A.zzz
#ERROR: ex.pydml [line 8:0] -> a=load("data/A.zzz") -- Read input file does not exist on FS (local mode): data/A.zzz

a = True
b = False
c = (a && b)
#ERROR: ex.dml [line 12:4] -> (a && b) -- Conditional AND (&&) not supported.
#PYDML Handled at parse level

x = full("1 2 3 4 5 6", rows=2, cols=3)
[P, L, U] = lu(x)
#ERROR: ex.dml [line 16:0] -> [P, L, U] = lu(x) -- LU Decomposition requires a square matrix. Matrix x is 2x3.
#ERROR: ex.pydml [line 21:0] -> [P,L,U]=lu(x) -- LU Decomposition requires a square matrix. Matrix x is 2x3.

a = blah("hi")
#ERROR: ex.dml [line 19:0] -> a = blah("hi"); -- Function blah() is undefined.
#ERROR: ex.pydml [line 25:0] -> a=blah("hi") -- Function blah() is undefined.

x = full("1 2 3 4", rows=2, cols=2)
y = table(x)
#ERROR: c.dml [line 23:0] -> y = table(x) -- Invalid number of arguments to table(). The table() function requires 2, 3, 4, or 5 arguments.
#ERROR: c.pydml [line 30:0] -> y=table(x) -- Invalid number of arguments to table(). The table() function requires 2, 3, 4, or 5 arguments.

a = min(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
#ERROR: ex.dml [line 26:0] -> a = min(1, 2, 3, 4, 5) -- Invalid number of arguments for function min(). This function only takes 1 or 2 arguments
#PYDML Handled at parse level

a = min(1)
#ERROR: ex.dml [line 29:0] -> a = min(1) -- Expecting matrix argument for function min().
#ERROR: ex.pydml [line 36:0] -> a=min(1) -- Expecting matrix argument for function min().

a=full("1 2 3 4", rows=2, cols=2)
print(a)
#ERROR: ex.dml [line 33:0] -> print(a); -- Print statements can only print scalars. To print a matrix, please wrap it in a toString() function.
#ERROR: ex.pydml [line 41:0] -> print(a) -- Print statements can only print scalars. To print a matrix, please wrap it in a toString() function.
```

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/2006/
Ready for review (I believe). The changes have been made. Thanks.
@nakul02 Redirecting the stats to standard error if an error occurs seems like a simple, elegant solution that meets all requirements and minimizes impact on the perf scripts. Great idea.
Thanks @deroneriksson
LGTM. Thanks @nakul02
This seems just a bit odd to me. If you want to check for errors, please directly check for errors instead of relying on a brittle indirection over the stats output.
@mboehm7 Grepping for "our distinct error message" actually seems brittle to me. Why couple perf test code to strings generated in another part of the project?

Just define proper error codes and constants for relevant messages. This would actually allow you to run the perf tests without stats, which will be necessary for algorithms like decision tree (with fine grained access), where time measurements for all operations dominate performance by more than 3x.

@mboehm7 - this solution solves 2 problems - making the perf script simpler and not hindering your workflow. 
I am struggling to understand your objection to this solution.

I believe `scripts/perftest/python/requirements.txt` is causing the automated build to fail when it checks for licenses since requirements.txt doesn't have a license at the top of the file. To fix, could you add an exclusion in the pom.xml file to the `apache-rat-plugin` section (for example, `<exclude>scripts/perftest/python/requirements.txt</exclude>`)?

Hi @niketanpansare ,  
1. can you please help me with, how can I test this for scalability. I don't have a machine to test this, so if possible, how can I test that with jenkins CI. 
2. Also, I am stuck at some places in the algorithm can you please help there.(?)
In `SVD.dml`,
```
62 + [Q, R] = qr::QR(X, nb); //scalable qr decomposition, nb = no. of blocks
63 +
64 + [V, S, temp] = svd(R); //computes svd locally
```
the `QR` function is a scalable decomposition, calculating `R` matrix. The local `svd` of `R` matrix is then calculated. But how then after that, we would get the whole of result by combining all the blocks.

 Thanks.

>> 1. how can I test this for scalability?

If you don't have access to a cluster, then I recommend using `--num-executors` set to 2+ and adjusting the size of X accordingly as a naive way to test the scalability. (Note: the objective of scalability here is not necessarily large matrix that doesnot fit in RAM, but large matrix that doesnot fit on the driver).

Hi @j143. I believe there are a couple issues.

1) Looking at the LinearRegCG.dml script, it looks like the author of the LinearRegCG.dml script inconsistently made the input matrix 'y' lowercase (rather than uppercase, like 'X'). Therefore, `.in("Y", Y)` needs to be `.in("y", Y)`.
2) Secondly, there is no variable 'B' in the script, so defining 'B' as a variable that shall be output via `.out("B")` will fail. You could obtain 'beta_out', so `out("beta_out")` would work.

Also, note that no checks are being performed for expected results. I think that is probably fine at this stage, since these test demonstrate that these scripts can indeed be executed using the MLContext API.
